subject: Re: [junit] Help,what's wrong with my TDD practice in my daily life?
msgSnippet: Hi James, ... Well, I never suggested not writing tests, I was just saying that sometimes, it s okay to write your tests once you re done with the business
messageBody:
Hi James,

On 9/10/07, James Carr <james.r.carr@...> wrote:

> On 9/10/07, you wrote:
> >
> > Just like everything else, use TDD sparingly. I understand you are
> > currently doing this as an exercise, so it's healthy to take it to
> > extremes and do everything by the book in order to learn, but in your
> > real work, use your judgment and decide for yourself when you are
> > indeed writing too much code, in which case it's probably safer to go
> > the usual route (get your code to work, then write tests for it).
> >
> > The downside of TDD is that you can end up writing a lot of tests for
> > business code that you quickly throw away and rewrite, so the amount
> > of churn can be quite high.
> >
>
> I disagree. When I've found something difficult to write test first
> I've always done a spike, then delete the code and rewrote it test
> first. I've always found the result to be a lot more cleaner,
> especially since I wind up cleaning up the code anyway when I used to
> write tests around them.
>
> I'd rather have my business code tested rather than not test it under
> the assumption it will one day be thrown away. ;)

Well, I never suggested not writing tests, I was just saying that
sometimes, it's okay to write your tests once you're done with the
business code.

Here is a scenario I've seen happen fairly often:

Write test1
Write code1
Write test2
Write code2

Then a refactoring comes to mind and you realize you don't need code1
and code2 any more, so you write code3, and suddenly, you find
yourself having to refactor (or throw away) both test1 and test2.

I was simply suggesting that sometimes, the following flow works better:

Write code1
Write code2
<realize a refactoring is possible>
Refactor code1/code2 into code3
<happy with the result, now we write the test>
Write test3

Net result: two less tests to write.

--
Cédric
Author "Next Generation Testing in Java" (http://tinyurl.com/yvyxa3)
